channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: South Korea’s impeached president has been detained after police executed arrest warrant, prosecutors say
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol, who is facing insurrection charges after his effort to impose martial law last month, becomes the first South Korean president to be detained while in office. Prosecutors now have 48 hours to formally arrest him.

item.title: The SEC sues Elon Musk over late disclosure of Twitter share purchases, citing an underpayment of $150 million
item.description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered Musk to pay a civil penalty and other remedies over what the regulator alleged was an act of “unjust enrichment.”

item.title: Biden establishes new national monuments in California, making more than 850,000 acres off limits to development
item.description: President Joe Biden signed proclamations Tuesday creating the 624,000-acre Chuckwalla National Monument and the 224,000-acre Sáttítla Highlands National Monument. The move bans oil and gas drilling, mining and other industrial activities on these vast swaths of public land, which several Native American tribes have considered sacred for thousands of years.

item.title: Pete Hegseth faced Democrats’ ire over his views on women in combat, and claims of sexual assault and excessive drinking
item.description: Senate Democrats on Tuesday hammered Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump’s pick for defense secretary, in an early test of Republican loyalty as lawmakers take up the incoming administration’s slate of unconventional and contentious Cabinet picks. The hearing quickly became a heated, rhetorical battle along partisan lines — marked at times by raised voices.

item.title: Biden is lifting Cuba’s state sponsor of terrorism designation, just days before leaving the White House
item.description:
The Cuban government is expected to free “a significant number of political prisoners” under an agreement it has made with the Catholic church, according to a senior Biden administration official.
The incoming Trump administration is almost certain to reverse the lifting of the terrorism designation.

item.title: House passes bill banning transgender students from women’s sports teams. Its fate in the Senate is unclear.
item.description: Republicans, who elevated the issue as one of their 2025 priorities, argued that the legislation would protect girls and women from unfair competition and guard against safety concerns. Democrats called the measure a harmful and impractical distraction.

item.title: Six takeaways from the Trump Jan. 6 report by special counsel Jack Smith
item.description: Smith’s report on Donald Trump’s alleged attempts to subvert the results of the 2020 election argues that Trump would have been convicted at trial and gives new insights into the investigative process. Here’s what we learned.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Unsure how to respond to the death of ‘hateful bigot’ dad
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Unsure how to respond to the death of ‘hateful bigot’ dad

item.title: Happening now: Can the Commanders keep up this winning streak against the top-seeded Lions? Our reporters take your questions.
item.description: The Commanders keep winning — dramatically — and find themselves in the NFC divisional round against the Detroit Lions. Beating the Buccaneers in the first round was impressive, but the Lions (15-2) will offer another level of competition. Sports columnist Barry Svrluga and Commanders beat writers Nicki Jhabvala and Sam Fortier are answering your questions about the team and their playoff matchup.

item.title: Pete Hegseth, Trump’s controversial pick to lead the Pentagon, faces a tough Senate confirmation hearing. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: The former Fox News host tapped by President-elect Donald Trump to become defense secretary is expected to face questions about allegations of sexual assault, excessive drinking and sexism — allegations he’s denied. Senators are also likely to ask questions about his long history of public commentary deriding minorities and people with opposing political views.

item.title: Trump report. Los Angeles fires. Pete Hegseth hearing. Ceasefire talks. AI arrests. Dementia risk. Cellphone ban. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump would have been convicted in D.C. if he wasn’t elected, special counsel Jack Smith says in report
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump tried to block the release of Smith’s report on his federal investigation of Trump’s alleged efforts to overturn Joe Biden’s 2020 election victory. The case was dismissed after Trump was elected in November, because Justice Department policy prohibits prosecuting a sitting president.

item.title: Special counsel defends Hunter Biden prosecution, chides President Biden for questioning investigation
item.description: The special counsel who investigated President Joe Biden’s son Hunter defended his prosecution on gun and tax charges in a report released Monday, pushing back on claims by the president and his family that the cases were politically motivated.

item.title: Police use facial recognition as it was never intended: As a shortcut to finding and arresting suspects without further evidence
item.description: Confident in unproven facial recognition technology, sometimes investigators skip steps, and at least eight Americans have been wrongfully arrested, a Washington Post investigation found.

item.title: 2 in 5 U.S. adults are likely to develop some form of dementia after age 55, a sobering new study finds
item.description: A study published Monday in the journal Nature Medicine projects that the risk people face over their lifetime of developing the memory-robbing condition is higher than some previous estimates. The new analysis is based on decades of close follow-up, including regular cognitive assessments, of a racially diverse group of people — a quarter of whom were Black and face an increased risk of dementia.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Will rewards entice a traumatized kid to reengage with school?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Will rewards entice a traumatized kid to reengage with school?

item.title: How New Orleans failed to protect Bourbon Street from the deadly New Year’s truck attack, block by block
item.description: A poorly positioned police SUV and a plan that called for only a single anti-vehicle barrier on the street that night were among the failures that allowed an ISIS-inspired attacker to drive a truck down the pedestrian thoroughfare in the early hours of Jan. 1, killing 14 people and injuring dozens, according to a Washington Post examination.

item.title: An Albuquerque home is the star of today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Los Angeles fires. Trump inauguration. Ceasefire talks. TikTok ban. Pain pill. NFL playoffs. Bat surfing. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Commanders beat Buccaneers in Jayden Daniels’s NFL playoff debut
item.description: Washington won, 23-20, on Sunday night in Tampa and will play at the Detroit Lions in the second round next weekend. It is Washington’s first postseason victory since 2006 and continues a breakout season for the franchise and its rookie quarterback.

item.title: Landlords are accused of colluding to raise rents. See whether this is happening near you.
item.description: Millions of rents across the country may now be set using one company’s algorithmic software, according to a federal lawsuit and a Washington Post analysis. RealPage, a property management software company, uses a trove of data to suggest rental prices to landlords. The software has been widely adopted by property managers — and is now facing strenuous legal pushback. Look at just how widespread its use may be.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: We moved to the suburbs, and I’m miserable. I blame my husband.
item.description: Ask Sahaj: We moved to the suburbs, and I’m miserable. I blame my husband.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: What makes Commanders wide receiver Terry McLaurin great? See for yourself.
item.description: Washington’s star, who will appear in his second career playoff game Sunday night against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, is elite at ball-tracking, a skill that is difficult — but not impossible — to measure.

item.title: Streets turned to ash: Before and after the Los Angeles fires, in photos and videos
item.description: Multiple wildfires have devoured neighborhoods in Los Angeles. Here’s what some of these areas looked like before the catastrophic blazes — and what they look like now.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Jack Smith, the special counsel named to oversee the federal cases against Donald Trump, resigns from the Justice Department
item.description: The news came in a footnote of a court filing. Smith spent the last two months winding down the two federal criminal prosecutions of Trump and said he would resign before Inauguration Day.

item.title: Largest of L.A. fires is creeping closer to the 405 freeway, triggering a new wave of alarm as flames spread. Follow our coverage.
item.description: When flames from the Palisades Fire appeared to spread east to Mandeville Canyon, locals knew that meant the blaze was creeping closer to Interstate 405, near a busy mountain pass.

item.title: The original, science‑backed 7‑minute workout to get fit fast
item.description: Research shows this simple routine can rapidly improve endurance and health — no gym required. The workout features 30 seconds of familiar calisthenics — exercises that use your own body weight, such as jumping jacks and push-ups — capped with five seconds of rest. Each calisthenic exercise should be somewhat challenging, said Chris Jordan, the exercise physiologist who developed the workout, feeling like “about an eight on a scale of effort from one to 10.”

item.title: See how a small fire in L.A. turned into a monster, hour by hour
item.description: As winds near Pacific Palisades approached extreme levels, the first signs emerged of a fire that would later grow out of control. Videos and images taken by residents and area-camera networks show how each hour after that, the blaze grew stronger, spreading from hilltops and eventually through a densely populated and beloved community. In the coming days, the fire’s sheer devastation would become clearer.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Ukraine captured two North Korean soldiers in Russia, Zelensky says, in move that could shed light on Pyongyang’s role in the war
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky’s announcement marks Ukraine's first confirmation it has detained North Korean troops since they were deployed late last year. He said that capturing them alive “was not an easy task.”

item.title: ‘Significant’ flare-up of Palisades Fire prompts expansion of evacuation orders in Los Angeles
item.description: The upgraded orders now cover much of the Brentwood neighborhood. The Getty museum, a Los Angeles landmark, is in the area affected by the orders. A Cal Fire spokesperson said the flare-up is a “significant development” and that the Palisades Fire — which has burned more than 21,000 acres — is growing “really, really fast.”

item.title: The death toll in the California fires rises to 11 people. Gov. Newsom launches a water supply investigation. Follow our coverage.
item.description: As firefighters battle six blazes, California Gov. Gavin Newsom has launched a probe of lost water supply and pressure in Los Angeles’s municipal water systems during the fires.

item.title: Biden shields nearly 1 million immigrants from Venezuela, El Salvador, Ukraine and Sudan from deportation for 18 months
item.description: The Biden administration on Friday extended temporary humanitarian protections for nearly 1 million immigrants living in the United States, announcing the move days before the start of a possible deportation campaign by the incoming Trump administration. Advocates had been urging the Department of Homeland Security to extend the protected designation for these nationalities and others under a 1990 law that shields immigrants from being deported to countries engulfed in conflict or natural disasters.

item.title: ‘We don’t cry — yet’: A Pacific Palisades native on what has been lost
item.description: "The Pacific Palisades was a village, my village — and now it’s gone," E.A. Hanks writes.

item.title: Winter weather advisory for light snow issued for D.C. area
item.description: Snow is expected to move into the area around 10 p.m. Friday and continue into early Saturday morning. One to two inches could fall, causing slippery roads.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: How do I get my instincts back after a bad relationship?
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: How do I get my instincts back after a bad relationship?

item.title: Supreme Court appears likely to clear the way for ban or sale of TikTok
item.description: After more than two hours of exchange with lawyers for the Chinese-owned social platform, its users and the U.S. government, a majority of the justices seemed to embrace Congress's national security concerns over the free speech implications of the law.

item.title: Biden administration targets two of Russia’s largest oil companies and 183 oil tankers in sanctions, delivering a parting blow
item.description: The White House, now less concerned about the effect on gas prices and inflation, also has measures against a list of entities involved in virtually all sectors of Russia’s energy business in a move to put pressure on President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: The Supreme Court is hearing a challenge to the law ordering that TikTok be either banned in the U.S. or sold. Follow our coverage.
item.description: Justices are listening to oral arguments on the Chinese-owned social platform’s claim that the law, based on national security concerns, violates free speech guarantees for its owners and some 170 million U.S. users.

item.title: Trump sentenced without penalty in hush money case, formalizing his status as first president or president-elect who is a felon
item.description: Trump was convicted in May on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with a hush money payment made to an adult-film actress during the 2016 presidential campaign. On Thursday the Supreme Court rejected a bid by Trump’s attorneys to stop the sentencing on the grounds that it would interfere with his transition to a second term as president after his November election victory.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Employers added 256,000 jobs in December, a strong uptick in the labor market, which sped up toward the end of 2024
item.description: The December report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics adds more evidence that the labor market is healthy enough to allow the Federal Reserve to be more cautious about lowering interest rates in 2025.

item.title: Los Angles fires. Trump sentencing. Carter funeral. TikTok ban. La Niña. College football. ‘Breaking Bad’ house. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: 2024 was the hottest year on record, scientists say, reaching 1.6 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels
item.description: The world’s nations have pledged not to breach the threshold of 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) for a sustained period of time, and new data from the European Union’s Copernicus Climate Change Service means the globe is edging closer to that mark. Aside from Australia and Antarctica, every continent experienced its warmest year on record.

item.title: Appeals court allows release of special counsel report on Trump’s Jan. 6 case
item.description: A federal appellate court has cleared the way for the Justice Department to publicly release special counsel Jack Smith’s report on Donald Trump’s efforts to undo the results of the 2020 election. The timing of that release remains unclear, however, and the ruling could be appealed.

item.title: NFL moves Rams-Vikings playoff game from Southern California to Arizona because of wildfires
item.description: The Monday night game, which was scheduled to be held at the Rams’ home in Inglewood, California, will instead be played at State Farm Stadium, the Phoenix-area home of the Arizona Cardinals. It is the last of six first-round playoff games.

item.title: Supreme Court refuses to delay Trump’s hush money sentencing in New York on Friday
item.description: The trial judge has said his sentence will not include jail time or probation for Donald Trump's felony conviction on charges of falsifying business records related to a hush money payment. The sentencing hearing will be the final step in Trump being formally classified as a felon.

item.title: Venezuelan opposition leader is detained after attending anti-Maduro protests on eve of inauguration
item.description: María Corina Machado, the driving force of Venezuela’s opposition movement, was arrested by government security forces Thursday as she left a rally in Caracas on the eve of Nicolás Maduro’s inauguration after a widely discredited election.
